awd_titl_txt: CRII: SaTC: Investigation of Side-Channel Attack Vulnerability in Near-Threshold Computing Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Security breaches in computing systems cost billions of dollars in economic damages every year, and the intangible destructive consequences left by malicious attacks are inestimable. Meanwhile, near-threshold computing (NTC) emerges as a promising solution to improve energy efficiency by reducing the supply voltage, making it attractive for a broad range of applications from Internet-of-Things (IoT) devices to cloud computing facilities. With the anticipated adoption of NTC in mainstream computing systems, security vulnerabilities that are unique to NTC will be ripe for exploitation. The objective of this project is to, for the first time, address NTC security concerns by performing a thorough and systematic investigation of its unique vulnerabilities to Side-Channel Attack (SCA) - attacks that rely on information leaked from the physical implementation of a cryptosystem.
Side-channel attacks are perhaps one of the most covert and sophisticated among cyber threats. 

Instead of treating security as an after-thought in traditional hardware development, in this project, we explore early-stage preventative methods to identify secure concerns in the design phase across different hardware implementation layers, and investigate the fundamental trade-off between efficiency and security in computing systems. Our investigation of the security implications of NTC will provide critical insights and methodologies for designing future efficient and secure computing systems. Due to its multi-disciplinary nature, our research project will promote the development and training of a strong workforce well-versed in the critical security domain across circuit design, computer architecture, and cryptography.

por.por_cntn:
This project aims to investigate the security implication in conventional digital systems when they are operating under non-nominal conditions and to deepen our understanding of the crucial tradeoff between energy efficiency and system security in modern computing platforms. Throughout the project, we are able to invesitgate several system security problems that fit under this scope.

First, we look at the system performance with near-threshold operation (i.e. the supply voltage is lowered to just above the transistor threhold voltage) to identify the unique side channels that have been introduced due to near-threshold operation and could expose the system to additional security vulnerabilities. Our findings suggest that on-chip memory can be particular sensitive to supply voltage, but at the same time offers energy saving opportunities if a dual-supply scheme can be adopted.

Next, our research expands to a broader class of side channels that leverage the intricate analog/mixed-signal behaviors that hide in plain sight inside conventional digital systems and their peripherral circuitry. We are able to develop a suite of model-driven approaches to design, detect, monitor, and defend against sneaky analog attacks on digital computing systems, be it from charge-domain Trojans such as A2 and Rowhammer attacks or side channels induced by the ubiquitous power delivery system that cause information leakage and fault injection. Many of these analog attacks analysis tools and methodology developed by us have been made available to not only the research community but also the general public.

Finally, with the support of this research award, we have also been able to push forward our work on designing lightweight hardware security primitives for resource-constrianed systems such as low power edge computing nodes or Internet-of-Things devices. We have successfully demonstrated lightweight implementation of reconfigurable blockchain primitives and commodity flash-compatible true random number generator on commerical off-the-shelf (COTS) platforms that can deliver comparable security functionality and performance at a fraction of the hardware resources and power/energy cost as compared to current state-of-the-art solution.

Like many research explorations, sometimes we stumble upon a less-trodden path that can lead to unexpected discovery and novel approaches. In this project, we have taken a different approach to understanding the fundamental mechanims of information leakage by looking at the signal representation in both analog and digital domains and its optimal conversion between the two. The result is a a novel neural network-inspired design framework that leverages deep learning to discover the optimal design of analog-to-digital converters. We are also able to make signficant progress on the exploration of a novel hardware approach to preventing transient power fluctuation from being probed by investigating a non-reciprocal energy transfer concept that has been demonstrated in parity-time-symmetric systems and leverage this amazing phenomenon in the electronic domain.

With respect to broader impacts, all of our research findings have been disseminated to the general public through publication of peer-reviewed conference and journal papers and open source release of the tools and methods on our group GitHub repo (https://github.com/xz-group). This award also provided significant exposure to and professional training on topics in computer architecture, energy-efficient computing, memory systems, and hardware security to a number of posdoctoral scholars, graduate students, and  undergraduate researchers involved in this project. Since the inception of the project, two master students have defended their master thesis and three Ph.D. students have been partially funded for their training. Three undergraduate students have been able to get exposure to research expeirence through the REU supplement associated with the award. Finally, two invention disclosures have been filed under the support of the award,
